subject: Redfish: Implement new event log propety Resolved
commitMessage:
Redfish: Implement new event log propety Resolved

In the new Redfish specification 2020.4，the eventlog propety "resolved"
is added.
This attribute indicates whether the log is marked as "resolved".

Tested:
Validator succeeded.
The "Modified" attribute value will also change accordingly.
This property can be changed as the "marked as resolved" is
modified on the web page, or it can be modified directly using the
redfish command.
Before marked the log as resolved:
~$ curl -i -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/1
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/1",
  "@odata.type": "#LogEntry.v1_8_0.LogEntry",
  "Created": "1970-01-01T00:01:09+00:00",
  "EntryType": "Event",
  "Id": "1",
  "Message": "xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Device.Error.ReadFailure",
  "Modified": "1970-01-01T00:01:09+00:00",
  "Name": "System Event Log Entry",
  "Resolved": false,
  "Severity": "Critical"
}%
after marked the log as resolved on webpage OR use the redfish commond:
~$ curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X PATCH -d '{"Resolved": true}' https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/1
~$ curl -i -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/1
{
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/1",
"@odata.type": "#LogEntry.v1_8_0.LogEntry",
"Created": "1970-01-01T00:00:57+00:00",
"EntryType": "Event",
"Id": "1",
"Message": "xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Device.Error.ReadFailure",
"Modified": "1970-01-01T00:03:05+00:00",
"Name": "System Event Log Entry",
"Resolved": true,
"Severity": "Critical"
}

Signed-off-by: Xiaochao Ma <maxiaochao@inspur.com>
Change-Id: Idd0cc0ca61ad56703303f90ba2bd1a372c321d94

This significantly changes how pagination works, as most implementations paginate the requests, and rely on the fact that leg entry items are immutable.  Considering that the Resolved field can be changed _after_ the log is created, this messes with pagination.

Can you please talk to this use case, and make recommendations for how the clients that implement pagination and polling should ensure that this parameter is caught.

I know IBM as well other companies use this, why Redfish added.

> how the clients that implement pagination and polling should ensure that this parameter is caught

Filter resolved logEntries out?

> Considering that the Resolved field can be changed _after_ the log is created, this messes with pagination.

How does it mess with pagination? Are you sorting by created/id? Could also sort by modified if it helps?

> I know IBM as well other companies use this, why Redfish added.
> 
> > how the clients that implement pagination and polling should ensure that this parameter is caught
> 
> Filter resolved logEntries out?

Can you describe this better?  Filtering out resolved logEntries doesn't fix the pagination problem, and arguably makes it worse, because you can actually miss events if they're resolved faster than your polling interval, unless i'm missing something about your idea.

> 
> > Considering that the Resolved field can be changed _after_ the log is created, this messes with pagination.
> 
> How does it mess with pagination? Are you sorting by created/id? Could also sort by modified if it helps?

If I want to write an interface that reads all logs, generally I would;

Query the log collection with start=0 and top=reasonable page size.
then increment start, polling the logs, until no entries are returned.
then would would monitor for new logs with start=currentIndex on some sort of loop

Doing this sort of log streaming relies on the fact that the ID for a given log entry is immutable, and logs of a given ID won't change.  This is how most paging collection APIs work.

If a log that happened in the past has the potential to change, now I can no longer rely on any of the above to get an accurate state of the logs at any give set of time unless the BMC changes the log ID every time the resolved field is changed, which it doesn't look like it does today.

> then would would monitor for new logs with start=currentIndex on some sort of loop

Ideally this would be something like Redfish events for "monitor for new logs"?

Can't you subscribe to redfish events for the log changes? As well as new logs?

How in the above case does the "interface that reads all logs" get updated when a log is deleted ?

> > then would would monitor for new logs with start=currentIndex on some sort of loop
> 
> Ideally this would be something like Redfish events for "monitor for new logs"?
> 
> Can't you subscribe to redfish events for the log changes? As well as new logs?

That's one way a client could implement, but not how most REST based log collection schemes were done when this was first committed.  Also, we didn't always have event service, so code got written against the collection that I'd really like to not break.

> 
> How in the above case does the "interface that reads all logs" get updated when a log is deleted ?


This usually isn't a concern for a streaming log service, but you make a good point, it wouldn't be registered.

> > How in the above case does the "interface that reads all logs" get updated when a log is deleted ?

> This usually isn't a concern for a streaming log service, but you make a good point, it wouldn't be registered.

If it isn't a concern for deleting a log, then I wouldn't think it would be a concern for resolved..

A log line changing after its happened is definitely a concern.  A log line getting deleted doesn't matter because most implementations assume they're on a circular buffer anyway.

I suspect we just need to update the IDs such that the unresolved log lines go after the resolved ones, and this problem goes away.
before
Done
Done

Can you do a test that doesn't involve marking it manually?  I can't imagine that the normal use case for this parameter would generally require manual intervention from a user.  I'm assuming you would normally expect the system to mark it resolved automatically when the condition fixes itself.

It is both. 
A user might mark the condition as fixed or the system might.

What's the behavior when the user marks it resolved?  This seems easy to define for oneshot events (like the read failure below), but for things like thresholds and other things, having a resolved flag would imply that when you "resolve" it, if the condition is still present, the event would get added to the top of the logs, right?  Is that the behavior in this case?

On systems that have the full phosphor-logging and phosphor-led stacks enabled (like witherspoon), an unresolved error log that has a FRU callout will light the fault LED for that FRU. When Resolved is set to true, the LED turns off. 
Also on witherspoon (phosphor-fan and phosphor-power repos), the code will automatically resolve the log when a fan or PS is replaced.

Regardless of the auto-resolve behavior, our service team wants the ability for the user to be able to set this themselves, so event logs that the user or the service team have already dealt with can be ignored.

There may be code added in the future watch for FRUs being replaced (new SN for a processor for example) and Resolve all logs that had that FRU as a callout.

> On systems that have the full phosphor-logging and phosphor-led stacks enabled (like witherspoon), an unresolved error log that has a FRU callout will light the fault LED for that FRU. When Resolved is set to true, the LED turns off. 
> Also on witherspoon (phosphor-fan and phosphor-power repos), the code will automatically resolve the log when a fan or PS is replaced.
> 
> Regardless of the auto-resolve behavior, our service team wants the ability for the user to be able to set this themselves, so event logs that the user or the service team have already dealt with can be ignored.

Ok, I guess I can buy that.  

> 
> There may be code added in the future watch for FRUs being replaced (new SN for a processor for example) and Resolve all logs that had that FRU as a callout.
